Describe factors that make bipolar disorder difficult to diagnose. 3. Describe nursing interventions for behaviors associated with mania. 4. List three medications useful in treatment of bipolar disorders and the potential side effects of each. Copyright ©2023 F.A. Davis Company Learning Outcomes (continued) 5. Describe two teaching points for bipolar patients on mood stabilizers. Copyright ©2023 F.A. Davis Company Bipolar Disorder ▪ A disorder characterized by mood swings from profound depression to extreme euphoria with intervening periods of normalcy Copyright ©2023 F.A. Davis Company Bipolar Disorder Terms ▪ Cyclothymic—Characterized by chronic mood disturbance involving numerous episodes of hypomania and depressed mood with less intensity ▪ Hypomania—A mild form of mania ▪ Mania—Predominant mood that is elevated, expansive or irritable with frenzied motor activity. Also known as manic episodes. Copyright ©2023 F.A. Davis Company Types of Bipolar Disorders ▪ Bipolar I—the classic image of bipolar disorder with manic symptoms and most likely depressive episodes ▪ Bipolar II—recurrent bouts of major depression with episodic occurrence of hypomania. This patient may never have experienced a full episode of mania. Copyright ©2023 F.A. Davis Company Types of Bipolar Disorders (continued) ▪ Cyclothymic—a chronic mood disturbance of at least a 2-year duration involving numerous episodes of hypomania and depressed mood but of less intensity Copyright ©2023 F.A. Davis Company Causes ▪ Altered levels of serotonin, dopamine, and/or norepinephrine will have an effect on mood. Increased levels are believed to be present in manic episodes and decreased in depressive ones. ▪ Genetics (from studies of twins) Copyright ©2023 F.A. Davis Company Causes (continued) ▪ A combination of genetics and biochemical factors along with environmental triggers such as stressful life events may present the most comprehensive picture. ▪ Medical conditions and medications can trigger an episode in susceptible people. Copyright ©2023 F.A. Davis Company Facts About Bipolar Disorders ▪ 4.4% of the American population will suffer from this disorder in their lifetime ▪ Affects males and females at approximately the same rate ▪ Episodes may or may not be associated with periods of depression ▪ Average age of onset is 25 Copyright ©2023 F.A. Davis Company Facts About Bipolar Disorders (continued) ▪ After the first episode, there is a high risk of recurrence ▪ Some have periodic episodes separated by years and others have much more frequent cycles ▪ Most common cause of postpartum psychosis Copyright ©2023 F.A. Davis Company Symptoms ▪ The manic phase may last from days to months and cause marked disruption of occupational and social functioning. It can include psychotic features. ▪ The depressed phase of bipolar disorder is similar to those described for major depressive disorders in Chapter 11. Copyright ©2023 F.A. Davis Company Manic Symptoms ▪ Very elevated mood • Excess activity (hyperactivity) • Increased energy • Racing thoughts, flight of ideas • Talking a lot • Very high self-esteem (false beliefs about self or abilities) Copyright ©2023 F.A. Davis Company Manic Symptoms (continued_1) ▪ Easily distracted ▪ Little need for sleep (may feel rested after 3 hours of sleep) ▪ Poor temper control, easily agitated and irritable ▪ Reckless behavior and lack of self-control including: • Drinking, and/or drug use, binge eating • Poor judgment • Sex with many partners (promiscuity) • Spending sprees Copyright ©2023 F.A. Davis Company Manic Symptoms (continued_2) ▪ In the early phase of a manic episode an individual can become more engaging and outgoing with high achievement, energy, and success. As a manic phase accelerates, this individual can become frenzied and out of control, leading to impaired decision making and potentially hazardous actions. Copyright ©2023 F.A. Davis Company Medical Treatment ▪ Mood stabilizer medications are the primary treatment ▪ Psychotherapy helps with support and medication compliance Copyright ©2023 F.A. Davis Company Mood Stabilizers ▪ Lithium ▪ Anticonvulsants including carpamazepine (Tegretol), gabapentin (Neurontin), valproic acid (Depakene), lamotrigine (Lamictal) ▪ Additional medications may include antianxiety and antipsychotic drugs in some patients Copyright ©2023 F.A. Davis Company Lithium Monitoring ▪ Lithium requires close monitoring including regular blood levels. Therapeutic levels are between 0.5–1.2 milliequivalents per liter for most patients (1.0–1.5 in acute mania). ▪ The blood levels can become elevated in dehydration, profuse sweating, and chronic diarrhea leading to toxicity. ▪ Toxicity can cause tremors, confusion, seizures, coma, and even death. Copyright ©2023 F.A. Davis Company Lithium Monitoring (continued) ▪ Early warning signs of toxicity include nausea, vomiting, and sedation. Copyright ©2023 F.A. Davis Company Clicker Question 1. What is considered a therapeutic lithium blood level in a stable patient? A. 1.0–1.5 milliequivalents per liter B. 10–15 milliequivalents per liter C. 0.5–1.2 milliequivalents per liter D. 0.05–0.1 milliequivalents per liter Copyright ©2023 F.A. Davis Company Clicker Question (continued_1) 2. Which response is the most accurate list of signs of lithium toxicity? A. Nausea, tremors, confusion B. Increased manic symptoms C. Increased urine output, excessive thirst D. Nausea, agitation, hypertension Copyright ©2023 F.A. Davis Company Clicker Question (continued_2) 3. Which statement demonstrates the best approach to promote compliance with mood stabilizers? A. Patient knows he can stop these meds when manic symptoms decrease B. Patient and his family are educated on side effects C. If taking lithium, blood tests are only required the first 6 months of taking this drug D. Psychotherapy is not recommended once the manic state resolves Copyright ©2023 F.A. Davis Company Nursing Interventions ▪ Patience, patience, patience!!! ▪ Monitor lithium levels—monitor for side effects ▪ Promote honest/therapeutic communication ▪ Provide consistency in care ▪ Encourage healthy nutrition ▪ Encourage appropriate activity ▪ Provide clear, firm limits ▪ Ensure patient safety
